The incident occurred when the flame made contact with the animal. Both men, aged 18 and 24, were subsequently evicted from the island and charged with animal cruelty. Detectives seized video evidence and questioned the suspects, who will appear in court on April 17th.

The passage describes Alice Barker, a 102-year-old dancer who had never seen herself dance before due to lost photographs and films. Mark Cantor and volunteers created a video compilation called "soundies" to show her these early dance performances, which thrilled the elderly dancer.

The passage discusses a decline in Britons washing their own cars, with statistics showing that a third of men have never washed their car, and only 12% of those who do so do so regularly. The study attributes this trend to various factors including increased availability of car wash services, larger vehicle sizes, and less time available for such tasks. It also mentions that while some still prefer to wash their cars themselves, particularly in certain regions like Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield, others opt for professional services due to the convenience and cost-effectiveness.

The passage discusses Steven Gerrard's impact on Martin Skrtel during his time at Liverpool, praising Gerrard's leadership and influence. It also mentions Gerrard's upcoming FA Cup semi-final appearance and his aim to win the final on his birthday. The text highlights how Gerrard has helped Skrtel settle at Liverpool and the club's belief in finding replacements for Gerrard's role. Finally, it notes that both Gerrard and Skrtel are expected to play in the FA Cup semi-final due to recent suspensions.

Jack Nicklaus, at the age of 75, achieved a hole-in-one in the par-3 contest at Augusta National, becoming the oldest golfer to do so. This accomplishment was notable as it marked his first hole-in-one on the course and surpassed the previous record of five hole-in-ones set on the same day. Nicklaus' performance was part of a memorable Masters week where multiple players achieved the feat, including Camilo Villegas who also hit holes-in-one on the fourth and eighth holes. Despite Villegas' success, Nicklaus ultimately lost in a playoff to Kevin Streelman. Nicklaus has a rich golfing history, having won six Masters titles and being part of the five-man club that has completed the career grand slam.

A series of storms swept through Kansas on Wednesday night, triggering tornado sirens and reports of at least one confirmed tornado near Goddard. The storm system continued moving northeastward, potentially affecting other areas. Nighttime tornadoes were highlighted as particularly dangerous. Other states like Missouri were also impacted, with reports of wind damage, flooding, and hail in Potosi. More severe weather is forecasted for Thursday across multiple regions.

The passage describes an Oklahoma reserve deputy, Robert Bates, who was charged with second-degree manslaughter for fatally shooting Eric Harris during a weapons sting operation. Bates claimed he meant to use a Taser but accidentally used a gun. He pleaded not guilty at his hearing and was granted permission to take a vacation to the Bahamas. The family of Eric Harris criticized this decision, viewing it as insensitive given the circumstances. Bates' preliminary hearing is set for July 2nd. There are allegations of preferential treatment for Bates due to his donations and friendship with the sheriff, though the Tulsa County Sheriff's Office denies these claims. Two other deputies involved in the incident have been reassigned due to threats.

Conor McGregor is preparing for a featherweight title fight against Jose Aldo on July 11. He has unveiled two new tattoos: a gorilla eating a heart on his chest and a tiger's face on his stomach. McGregor believes Aldo lacks the same motivation to defend his title as he does to win it. They had a contentious interaction during a promotional tour in Dublin where McGregor snatched Aldo's belt in front of 5,000 fans. McGregor is eager to prove himself as the rightful champion before the fight.

The passage discusses Tony Abbott's participation in a beer-drinking event at an Australian Rules function, where he quickly consumed a schooner of beer. This action sparked controversy among anti-drinking campaigners who argue it promotes binge drinking and trivializes masculinity. Julie Roberts, a cultural studies professor, criticizes this behavior, stating it normalizes excessive drinking and encourages unhealthy drinking habits. Despite this backlash, Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott, suggesting alternative healthy activities could promote a healthier nation. The incident highlights differing views on alcohol consumption and its role in Australian culture.

The passage discusses a significant increase in HIV cases in Scott County, Indiana, following the implementation of a 30-day needle exchange program approved by Governor Mike Pence. The program has led to 120 confirmed HIV cases and 10 preliminary positives, compared to 106 cases the previous week. Health officials expect the number of cases to rise due to increased testing. The outbreak is linked to intravenous drug users and the use of Opana, a powerful painkiller. The program has been successful in providing 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants, though 1,400 used syringes have been returned. Governor Pence is considering extending the program, but there are concerns about its effectiveness and potential promotion of drug use. The future of needle exchange programs in Indiana remains uncertain, with legislative efforts underway to address the issue.

A football fan boyfriend created a test consisting of multiple-choice questions, tables to complete, and "in your own words" sections to quiz his girlfriend Saskia about Arsenal Football Club. He marked her answers with red pen, scoring her 43. 5 out of 50. Despite her poor performance, he decided not to break up with her. The test format included instructions such as "read every question at least twice" and "calculators may be used." Saskia scored 87% on the test, but her boyfriend criticized her for not knowing Arsenal's official abbreviation (FC), Arsenal's nickname (The Gunners), the current manager (Mikel Arteta), and the kit she wore (away kit). She struggled with the starting 11 squad and player positions. Her boyfriend graded her an 'A' and did not end their relationship. Some people praised the boyfriend for being a "legend," while others felt he had gone too far.

Carlos Toro, a DEA informant who worked undercover for 27 years, faced deportation due to his retirement. He previously worked for the Medellin cartel and fled Colombia fearing for his life. After coming to the US, he became a key asset for the DEA, helping in undercover operations worldwide. Despite his contributions, he did not receive US citizenship as promised. Now, with declining health, he faces deportation and fears returning to Colombia where he believes he would face immediate danger.

A 14-year-old Indian girl set herself on fire after allegedly being gang-raped by five men in her village, following an incident where she was forced to relieve herself outside her home. Her family reportedly silenced her about the attack. She is now in critical condition at Delhi's Safdarjung Hospital with severe burns. The accused men have been arrested, but the incident highlights ongoing issues of sexual assault and rising sensitivities in India, particularly following a controversial documentary about a previous rape case.

The passage discusses Manchester United's upcoming derby match against Manchester City, focusing on Robin van Persie's injury and Louis van Gaal's preparation for the game. Despite the absence of Van Persie due to ankle trouble, Van Gaal aims to secure a top-three finish to avoid Champions League qualification. The coach emphasizes the importance of winning the match, which could potentially secure third place in the league standings. Additionally, Van Gaal mentions that Luke Shaw is not yet fit to play, and he plans to avoid any hint of revenge motivation, instead focusing on the team's performance and the positive atmosphere at Old Trafford.

The passage describes a protest by Arsenal and Liverpool fans at the Emirates Stadium during a Barclays Premier League match, where they left their seats empty for the first 10 minutes due to dissatisfaction with rising ticket prices. The protest coincided with the announcement of a £5. 14 billion TV rights deal. Tickets for the 12:45 PM kick-off cost £64, making them among the most expensive in the Premier League. The protesters aimed to raise awareness about the financial burden on fans, displaying banners such as "£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket." The event was organized by fans' groups representing both clubs, with organizers calling the prices "extortionate" and expressing concern that fans might be lost if the situation continues.

A newborn baby diagnosed with biliary atresia, a condition affecting about 1 in 16,000 babies at birth, requiring a liver transplant due to blocked bile ducts. The baby's parents, unable to find a suitable liver donor, turned to their twin sister for a transplant. Her twin sister, Shanell Reader, agreed to donate part of her liver, saving the baby's life. The baby, named Star, underwent the transplant in November and has since recovered, though she continues to require regular medical check-ups and anti-rejection medication.

The passage describes Chelsea players participating in an Audi Football Challenge, showcasing their skills in various football-related challenges such as shooting balls into car boots and playing tennis over an Audi R8 V10 Plus. Eden Hazard and Nathan Ake performed well, securing victories in several rounds, including a decisive win in the final challenge where they sank balls through the top of a convertible Audi. However, Willian and Loic Remy managed to win against their teammates, albeit with a costly incident where Willian accidentally broke the wing mirror of one of the Audis during a long-range shot.

Robert Dellinger, a former Fortune 500 executive from New Hampshire, pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault charges after causing a fatal crash in December 2013. The accident, which occurred when he drove his pickup truck at over 100 mph across a median, killed 24-year-old Amanda Murphy, who was eight months pregnant, and her fiancé, Jason Timmons. Dellinger initially told investigators he was attempting suicide on that day but later denied being suicidal during his sentencing. He faces up to 24 years in prison. Dellinger's attorneys claimed he was suffering from medication issues and MS symptoms at the time of the crash.

A Kentucky woman, Lacey Spears, was convicted of second-degree murder for poisoning her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul, with salt at a New York hospital. She received a 20-year-to-life sentence but was spared the maximum 25 years. Her ex-husband, Chris Hill, expressed anger and desire for her to die in prison on Facebook. The judge noted that Spears suffers from a mental illness and described the crime as "unfathomable in its cruelty." Prosecutors claimed Spears used her son's health issues to gain attention, while Spears' lawyer argued she was innocent and blamed the hospital for negligence.

The passage discusses fears about two new influenza strains causing spikes in deaths in Europe and the US. It mentions that Australia's influenza vaccine has been delayed by a month due to including protection against these strains and another strain (H3N2 and B/Phuket). The vaccine is now modified to better match global circulating strains, aiming to prevent more deaths compared to previous years. High-risk groups, including the very young and old, and most Indigenous Australians, will receive free flu shots starting in April. Dr. Alan Hampson, an influenza specialist, emphasizes the importance of the vaccine for all, not just high-risk individuals, as it helps protect those in close contact with them.

The passage discusses the challenges faced by caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb in Springfield, Illinois, amidst budget cuts and a critical article in National Geographic. The site commemorates the 150th anniversary of Lincoln's assassination, but faces difficulties due to financial constraints and criticism. The tomb, designed by Larkin Mead and dedicated by Ulysses S. Grant in 1874, has undergone significant renovations and repairs. Despite these efforts, it has been criticized as having "all the historical character of an office lobby" in a recent National Geographic article. Additionally, the site's hours and staffing have been reduced due to budget cuts, leading to concerns among caretakers and visitors.

The passage discusses current fashion trends inspired by the 1990s and early 2000s, including bucket hats, camouflage prints, oversized clothing, Ugg boots, Daisy Dukes, Juicy Couture tracksuits, colored sunglasses, corsets as outerwear, and harem trousers. It highlights how some of these trends, particularly the bucket hat, camouflage print, and Ugg boots, are making a comeback, while others like corsets and harem trousers are still popular but in different forms. The article also mentions that celebrities and fashion-forward individuals are often at the forefront of bringing these trends back into vogue.

This passage covers various trending stories from a busy week, including natural phenomena (rainbows), cultural practices (exotic dancers at wakes in China), public figures' controversies (R.D.J.), cosmetic trends (lip plumping), historical reenactments (Alice Barker's prom), celebrity casting news (Ewan McGregor for Beauty and the Beast), actor transformations (Johnny Depp in Black Mass trailer), and humorous pregnancy announcements (reference to The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air).

The passage describes the Miami Open tennis tournament, focusing on Serena Williams' 700th career victory and subsequent celebrations. It mentions Andy Murray's 500th win and a large cake presented to him. The text also highlights Williams' semi-final progress against Sabine Lisicki and her upcoming match against Simona Halep. Additionally, it notes a close match between Williams and Lisicki, and Halep's victory over Sloane Stephens. The passage conveys the tournament's festive atmosphere, particularly around Williams' achievements.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani activist, ran a second-floor cafe in Karachi known as T2F, which served as a hub for discussions on technology, human rights, and women's entrepreneurship. Despite facing dangers due to her outspoken views on free speech and controversial topics such as Balochistan's insurgency, she continued to organize and lead discussions. Her activism included inviting speakers and hosting events that were often shut down by authorities, leading to her eventual assassination by gunmen who targeted her and her mother. Mahmud's life and work were seen as a beacon of hope and courage, inspiring many to speak out against censorship and advocate for freedom of thought and expression.

The passage describes Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old traditional healer and West Pakistan Refugee (WPR) living in India's Kashmir, where he faces discrimination due to his refugee status. Despite being born in India, he has been denied citizenship rights and cannot own property or vote in state elections. The situation has persisted for nearly 70 years, affecting generations of his family. However, there is growing hope that changes might occur with the rise of the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), which includes WPRS in its agenda. This shift in political power could potentially lead to improvements in their legal status and socio-economic conditions.

Yoshinori Muto, a forward for FC Tokyo, is considering joining Premier League champions Chelsea this summer. FC Tokyo's president Naoki Ogane confirmed that Chelsea has offered around £4 million for Muto. Muto aims to join a club where he can play regularly and develop his skills. Chelsea intends to loan Muto to Vitesse Arnhem next season. Despite these offers, Muto prefers to take his time and consider his options before making a decision. Real Zaragoza's manager Ranko Popovic praised Muto's potential and attributes his speed, strength, and confidence to his background. Chelsea's manager Jose Mourinho acknowledges Muto's talent but emphasizes that financial considerations and adhering to financial regulations are important factors in the club's transfer policy.

The passage discusses the shift towards allowing overseas players in rugby teams, particularly praising Australia's decision to select players based on their performance rather than their club affiliations. It highlights examples like Matt Giteau and Steffon Armitage, who have excelled at foreign clubs, and argues that England should follow suit, citing Jonny Wilkinson's success in France as evidence. The author criticizes England's current policy of not selecting overseas players, suggesting it undermines the spirit of the World Cup and limits the pool of talent available to the national team. The piece concludes by advocating for the inclusion of top international players in the England squad, emphasizing the importance of having the best possible team for the World Cup.

The passage discusses FireChat, an app that enables messaging without needing a web or mobile signal, facilitated by iOS's Multipeer Connectivity Framework. Open Garden then developed Greenstone, an egg-shaped device acting as a beacon to enhance wireless mesh networks, allowing messages to travel farther. FireChat has been downloaded over five million times and uses a local network system where each device (node) passes data to others. Greenstone, still in development, aims to extend this functionality by bridging short-range connections, making communication possible in areas lacking traditional connectivity, such as planes, undergrounds, and large gatherings.

Lillian Bustle, a burlesque performer from New Jersey, aims to challenge societal perceptions of the word "fat" by embracing it as a positive descriptor of her body. She uses her Ted Talk to discuss how women are often discouraged from acknowledging their physical attributes, leading to negative body image issues. Bustle highlights that despite societal pressures, exposure to diverse body types can lead to greater acceptance and tolerance. Her TED Talk, which discusses the importance of body positivity and the role of burlesque in promoting such attitudes, has garnered significant positive responses, including support from viewers who found inspiration in her message.

Theo Walcott, a Arsenal winger, has been frequently seen sitting on the bench due to limited playing time this season. He recently participated in a photoshoot with other Arsenal players and a runway model for Lanvin, an established fashion house. Despite his reduced playing time, Walcott occasionally comes on as a substitute, most notably in Arsenal's 0-0 draw with Chelsea. He is set to make his first start since March 14th against Hull City in their upcoming match.

The passage describes an auction of over 400 props and puppets from Rick Baker's Cinovation Studio, valued at up to $746,100. The auction includes items from various films such as Men in Black, Batman Forever, How the Grinch Stole Christmas, and Planet of the Apes. Notable items include the Alien Edgar Bug from Men in Black, valued at $40,000, and the Bat Gremlin from Gremlins 2, valued at $8,000. The auction will take place at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles, California, and online through PropStore.com on May 29th.

The passage describes the tragic death of Carwyn Scott-Howell, a seven-year-old British boy from Wales, who was skiing in the French Alps with his family. He became separated from his mother and fell down a 164-foot drop in dense woodland. His mother, Ceri, 44, and siblings Antonia, 9, and Gerwyn, 19, searched for him but found his body later. The family, including his father, expressed immense grief, describing Carwyn as a "daring, outgoing, and determined" child who brought joy to their lives. Authorities believe he ventured into the woods to reach a ski resort he saw from the trees, leading to his fatal fall. The incident highlights the dangers of winter sports and the profound impact such tragedies have on families.

The passage describes the story of Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old girl from Whitley Bay who developed anorexia due to extreme dieting and obsession with maintaining a "size zero" appearance. She initially survived on just one piece of fruit a day, leading to severe health issues including a dangerously slowed heart rate. After collapsing and being hospitalized, Laura spoke openly about the pressures she faced from society and media to be extremely thin. Her condition worsened until she was critically ill, prompting her family to seek professional help. Despite her struggles, Laura has since recovered and participated in a beauty pageant, emphasizing the importance of body positivity and realistic beauty standards.

The passage discusses Liverpool's unveiling of their new home kit, featuring a gingham design by New Balance, which includes a £300 million four-year sponsorship deal. It highlights Raheem Sterling's positive reception from Liverpool supporters, who encouraged him to stay, despite speculation about his future. The launch event included interviews with players discussing their commitment to the club and their excitement for the upcoming FA Cup semi-final. The new kit incorporates "Hold Nothing Back" as a message and tributes to the Hillsborough disaster victims.

A detailed map of dark matter, covering approximately 0.4% of the sky, has been created by University of Manchester researchers. This map, derived from data gathered by the Dark Energy Survey (DES) using the Dark Energy Camera on the Victor M. Blanco Telescope in Chile, is part of a series intended to create a 3D view of dark matter across one-eighth of the night sky. The map reveals clumps of dark matter and helps astronomers understand how galaxies formed in the universe. The DES aims to map 12. 5% of the entire sky over five years, with the goal of testing current cosmological theories and understanding the relationship between dark and visible matter. The project involves analyzing 130 million separate telescope images of galaxies, requiring significant computational resources.

Manchester United has intensified its pursuit of Psv Eindhoven's Memphis Depay, a 21-year-old starlet, by formally approaching the Eredivisie champions. Manager Louis van Gaal is eager to secure Depay as one of his initial signings for the upcoming summer transfer window. Van Gaal, previously familiar with Depay's talents, had included him in the Netherlands World Cup squad in 2014. Depay, known for his speed, skillful close control, and ability to shoot from distance, has been scoring consistently for Psv Eindhoven, netting 20 goals in 26 league matches this season. Despite Premier League rivals Tottenham's previous unsuccessful attempt to sign Depay for £15 million, Manchester United now appears to be in contention for his services, with Paris Saint-Germain also showing interest. Depay's performances, including a spectacular free-kick against Heerenveen, have earned him recognition as a potential future star, comparable to Arjen Robben and even better than a young Cristiano Ronaldo.

The passage describes a football match where Chelsea defeated Manchester City's youth team, taking a 3-1 lead. Tammy Abraham scored twice for Chelsea, putting the match beyond City's reach. Dominic Solanke scored late to seal the victory. Key players from both teams are mentioned, highlighting their performances and challenges faced.

Marco Rubio argues that people are "born with a sexual preference" and supports traditional marriage between one man and one woman. He opposes same-sex marriage as a constitutional right and believes states should regulate marriage definitions through legislative processes rather than courts. Despite his stance, Rubio acknowledges attending the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer, indicating he respects their choices. He does not support same-sex marriage but maintains his love for those he cares about regardless of their sexual orientation or marital status.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde embarked on a global cycling journey starting from London in 2018. They quit their restaurant jobs in Manchester and are traveling without a specific plan or agenda, aiming to explore various parts of the world pedal by pedal. Since leaving, they've covered nearly 7,000 miles across 16 countries, living frugally on less than three euros per person per day. They rely on free accommodations, hostels, and Couchsurfing for shelter, and their primary expenses are food, which amounts to about 2. 74 euros per person per day. The couple, meeting in Riga in 2011, has been documenting their journey through blogs and social media, sharing photos and experiences of their adventures in diverse landscapes, from the French Alps to Turkey's mountains. Their goal is to continue cycling into Asia and eventually across North America.

A couple from Texas, whose wedding in 2012 included a photo booth provided by James Evans of Premiere Photos, discovered that racially offensive messages were printed on the bottom of their photographs. The couple, who wish to remain anonymous, hired attorney Cathy Hale to sue Evans for allegedly printing "poor n***** party" on the photos. They learned about the issue months after the event, when the bride's sister informed them. James Evans denied the allegations and refused to apologize, instead telling the couple to "sue" him. The couple eventually decided to press charges after Evans failed to address the matter. They are now suing under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act, alleging negligence and breach of contract. The case involves a dispute over offensive captions printed on wedding photos, with mediation scheduled for the following morning, and a potential trial in July.

Mike Brown, who recently suffered a concussion, is adopting a cautious approach to recovery. He is uncertain about his return date for Harlequins' upcoming match due to his concussion. George North, another player, has been advised not to play this season after sustaining four concussions. Johnny Sexton was sidelined for 12 weeks previously. Brown, who was knocked out during England's match against Italy, emphasizes caution to avoid a long-term absence similar to those experienced by other players. He attributes his increased awareness of concussion symptoms to completing online modules and believes that recognizing and respecting these symptoms is crucial for preventing serious long-term effects.

The passage discusses a decline in sexual activity among British couples, attributed to increased smartphone usage and the blurring of boundaries between personal and professional life due to technological advancements. Research indicates a significant decrease in monthly sexual encounters from four times in 1990 to three times currently, with experts suggesting factors such as living alone and the constant connectivity facilitated by technology are contributing to this trend.

The passage discusses the dramatic decline in popularity and value of Tibetan Mastiffs in China due to government anti-corruption efforts and recent city-wide bans on large dogs. Previously highly valued and often given as gifts to officials, these dogs are now being sent to slaughterhouses where their meat is used in cheap hotpots. The breed's traditional use in Tibet for herding has led to its decline, with many dogs found in poor conditions in transport crates, some already dead or severely injured. The situation is exacerbated by unscrupulous breeders producing low-quality dogs through cross-breeding for profit. This has resulted in a surplus of unwanted dogs, contributing to the trend of theft and sale to slaughterhouses.

The passage discusses a survey conducted among 600 women in Paris who reported experiencing sexual harassment or gender-based assaults on public transport. Half of the victims reported being harassed before the age of 18. The survey highlighted that harassment ranges from insulting behavior to more severe acts like sexual attacks or rape. It revealed that one-third of women felt unsafe on public transport due to harassment, compared to only one-fifth of men. The issue is considered "invisible" as many incidents go unreported, leading to changes in daily routines and limiting women's freedom. This situation has prompted calls for a campaign to address the issue of sexist or threatening behavior on public transport. The survey also noted that perpetrators often feel they can act with impunity, and victims may not always recognize or articulate their experiences.

The passage discusses a competition organized by Direct Line to design and prototype products that address common everyday emergencies. These emergencies include forgetting to lock the door, losing keys, being stuck in traffic, losing important documents, and running out of phone battery. Various teams from Makerversity designed and prototyped solutions such as the Forget Me Lock, Nipper (a small mobile phone charger), Snooze (an alarm clock that silences notifications), and other innovative ideas like a parking pin and a relay app. The winners will be selected based on public voting and will potentially be developed further through a Kickstarter campaign.

The passage describes a controversy involving Vera Baird, the Police and Crime Commissioner for Northumbria, who awarded £500,000 to Victims First Northumbria, a charity she also directs. This allocation sparked an investigation by the Ministry of Justice due to allegations of a conflict of interest and improper use of public funds. The incident led to criticism from politicians and the media, with accusations of a "soap opera" within the police force. Chief Constable Sue Sim, who sits on the charity's board, is also under scrutiny. The controversy highlights issues surrounding the new powers granted to Police and Crime Commissioners (PCCs) to commission services for victims of crime, including potential conflicts of interest.

A gang of young men, including Corey Campbell, 21, Sandra Ng, 19, and Carl Halin, 18, subjected a 53-year-old man named Greg Valecce to a brutal assault in March/April 2014. The assault began when the group discovered Valecce had allegedly injured their pet cat. They beat, slapped, and spat on Valecce, tied him to a chair, and tattooed offensive messages on his body. Valecce sustained multiple injuries, including broken ribs, broken wrists, and facial fractures. The incident lasted approximately 42 hours. The group filmed the abuse, which included swastikas, stars of David, racial slurs, and a penis ejaculating on a rainbow. Valecce escaped and contacted authorities, leading to the arrests of the perpetrators. All four defendants pleaded guilty and were sentenced: Corey Campbell to 20 years in prison, Carl Halin to the same sentence, and Sandra Ng to 23 months in prison. Another defendant, Jennifer Pratt, is awaiting trial.
