Artpop, released by Lady Gaga, achieved commercial success, debuting at number one on the US Billboard 200 with first-week sales of 258,000 copies and selling 757,000 copies worldwide. It was her second consecutive number-one album in the US and the ninth best-selling album of 2013 globally. While music critics were generally mixed about the album, it was commercially successful.

In 2006, John Frusciante released his final album with the Chili Peppers titled "Stadium Arcadium," which was their last to include him as a guitarist. He announced his departure from the band in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher, serving as Prime Minister, introduced policies associated with Thatcherism, which earned her both praise and criticism, making her one of Britain's most significant political figures despite ongoing debates about her economic and social reforms.

Michael Andrew "Duff" McKagan, born on February 5, 1964, is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author who has also become known for his writing, contributing weekly columns to various websites including SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker, an English actor, is known for his acting roles while also narrating commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia is the capital of the autonomous community of Valencia, Spain's third-largest city, and the third-largest metropolitan area in the country. It has approximately 800,000 inhabitants in its administrative center and around 1. 7 to 2. 5 million in its metropolitan area. The Valencian Community, also known as the Valencian Country, surrounds the city and includes Valencia as its capital.
The passage summarizes that Buffy Summers is a character who was initially portrayed by Kristy Swanson in a film, and later by Sarah Michelle Gellar in a television series.
The series "Make It or Break It" concluded with its third and final season, which was announced on April 26, 2012, and its finale aired on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition is an interdisciplinary field combining linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering to enable computers to understand and convert spoken language into text. Applications include voice user interfaces, call routing, domotic control, search functionality, data entry, document preparation, speech-to-text processing, and aircraft direct voice input. Advances are marked by the use of deep learning methods by major tech companies like Google, Microsoft, IBM, and others, who publicly disclose their reliance on these techniques for their speech recognition systems.

Richard Alf, an American businessman and former comic book store owner, co-founded and served as the chairman of the San Diego Comic-Con International starting in 1970, which began as the Golden State Comic Book Convention in 1970 and was later renamed the "San Diego Comic Book Convention."
The passage describes "Fist of Legend" as a remake of "Fist of Fury," released in 1972, which featured Bruce Lee as its main actor.

The passage describes a golf tournament where Rory McIlroy of Northern Ireland shot a third consecutive 67 to reach 15 under par, tying with Van Zyl of South Africa at 16 under par. McIlroy highlighted his performance, mentioning an eagle on the 12th hole and a strong comeback after a difficult start. The article also mentions McIlroy's recent return from injury and his aim to win his third Race to Dubai title. Additionally, it notes other players' performances and standings in the tournament.

The passage discusses Bahrain's political situation, focusing on Sheikh Ali Salman's stance on national dialogue and reforms. It highlights the divide between reformists like Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa and hardliners such as the Prime Minister, who oppose dialogue due to fears of encouraging further demands. The article also mentions the historical context of a previous agreement between the opposition and the crown prince, which was abruptly ended by GCC troops. Additionally, it touches upon international perspectives, including the expectations for US Secretary of State John Kerry and the UK's role in pressuring Bahrain for human rights and democratic practices. Lastly, it addresses the ongoing struggle for peaceful demonstrations and the release of imprisoned opposition figures.

Christopher Hogwood, a prominent figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his home in Cambridge due to an illness that lasted several months. He was a founding member of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM), which he directed for over three decades. Hogwood was known for his work with numerous orchestras worldwide and his extensive recording career, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. He studied piano at Cambridge University and later became a key figure in historically informed music performance. Hogwood taught at prestigious institutions such as Harvard University, the University of Cambridge, and Cornell University. His contributions to music education and performance were recognized widely, with tributes praising his generosity, influence, and dedication to the field.

The passage discusses a significant decrease in homicide cases in Scotland, marking the lowest number since 1976 and half the level from nine years prior. It highlights that a sharp instrument, particularly knives, remains the primary method of homicide, accounting for 51% of cases. Despite this reduction, ongoing efforts are emphasized to prevent further loss of life and address issues related to alcohol misuse and irresponsible violence.

Bournemouth lost 2-1 to Sunderland in their Premier League match, scoring only once despite creating multiple chances. The loss marks the first time a team has lost to Sunderland in the league this season. Howe attributes the poor performance to a lack of confidence rather than skill, citing their previous six-goal victory over Hull as evidence. Despite being reduced to ten men after Steven Pienaar's dismissal, Bournemouth failed to score against Sunderland, who scored twice through Victor Anichebe and Jermain Defoe's penalty.

The passage discusses Australia's tough stance on immigration through its "stop the boats" policy, which involves detaining migrants attempting to enter by sea and sending them to offshore processing camps. This policy is criticized as brutal and inhumane, particularly in light of the tragic death of a Syrian child trying to reach Europe. The Australian government, led by Prime Minister Tony Abbott, defends the policy, attributing the deaths to illegal boats, while also making controversial statements about the Islamic State being worse than the Nazis. However, these comments are met with criticism from Jewish community leaders, who argue that such comparisons are inappropriate and disrespectful.

The passage discusses tensions between the United States and Russia over the ongoing conflict in Syria, particularly focusing on the intensification of attacks against civilians in Aleppo. It highlights the US's warning to suspend talks if Russia does not stop bombing Aleppo, followed by Russia's denial of involvement in a recent humanitarian aid convoy strike. The situation in Aleppo, where government forces have resumed an offensive, has led to civilian casualties and the displacement of 250,000 people. Both countries express dissatisfaction with each other's actions, with the US criticizing Russia for failing to uphold commitments and prevent further civilian harm, while Russia accuses the US of shifting blame and not fulfilling key conditions of the ceasefire agreement.

The Policy Exchange report suggests selling high-value social housing to generate £4. 5 billion annually, which could fund the construction of 80, 000 to 170, 000 new social homes. This initiative aims to address the shortage of affordable housing while reducing the number of expensive social housing units. Downing Street supports this idea, but Labour opposes it, arguing it could displace low-income families from expensive neighborhoods. The policy exchange claims it would create the largest social housing program since the 1970s, potentially benefiting the economy. However, critics argue it could lead to segregation and displacement of working-class families from affluent areas.

The passage describes the death of Gareth Colfer-Williams, aged 25, from measles in Swansea, where an epidemic has reached 942 cases. Despite recent asthma treatment and discharge from Morriston Hospital, he developed a rash and died at home. An inquest is planned to determine if measles was the primary cause of death, with further tests required. Since November, 83 people have required hospital treatment for measles. The family is unaware of how Mr. Colfer-Williams contracted measles, as none of his close contacts have it, including his vaccinated three-year-old daughter.

The passage describes Vincent Hudson, aged 54, being charged with an historical offense involving a boy under 16 years old, which reportedly occurred in 2001. He is scheduled to appear at North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

Guiseley and Gateshead played to a 1-1 draw in a National League match. Guiseley took the lead through Jake Lawlor's goal on 15 minutes, but Gateshead equalized via Wes York's strike on 62 minutes. Both teams had several chances, with key saves made by Guiseley's Jonny Maxted and Gateshead's Liam Hogan. The match ended with both teams unable to secure a win.

Bristol Sport Ltd intends to replace two stands to expand their football club's capacity. This project is a response to the delay of a proposed new stadium at Ashton Vale due to a town green application. The council approved the redevelopment in November, and majority shareholder Steve Lansdown confirmed that work will commence after signing a section 106 agreement and completing a six-week judicial review period. The club aims to start the construction in May if no judicial review challenges occur.

The passage discusses a seismic event caused by Cuadrilla's shale gas drilling operations in Lancashire, England. A 1.5 magnitude tremor occurred, prompting a suspension of drilling activities. This followed a previous tremor in April, both centered near Poulton-le-Fylde. The British Geological Survey (BGS) noted similarities between these quakes and fracking processes, which involve injecting pressurized water into rocks to release gas. Environmental concerns over potential contamination of drinking water supplies have led to controversy regarding fracking in the United States. Despite these issues, the Commons energy select committee recommended supporting fracking in the UK under strict regulations. The BGS continues to monitor fracking activities for potential seismic risks.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old piper from Liverpool, was found guilty of fraud after playing with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes in April 2015. Initially accused of collecting money for the campaign, Carpenter claimed he was simply busking and the banner was meant as a tribute to the victims, not to deceive. He had previously piped for the charity but denied using the banner to raise funds. Carpenter will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town scored three goals against Queens Park Rangers, with Grant Ward opening the scoring with a scuffed shot put. Luke Varney then scored an unopposed goal after a miscue by the Rangers' goalkeeper, Alex Smithies. Tom Lawrence completed the scoring with a calm finish. Ipswich had struggled for goals in recent games but had several other chances, including a header wide by Christophe Berra and a volley that went straight at Smithies. Ipswich improved their league position to 14th, while Queens Park Rangers dropped to 15th after their sixth consecutive away loss. Ipswich manager Mick McCarthy praised Luke Varney's performance, while Queens Park Rangers boss Ian Holloway criticized his goalkeeper's mistake and the team's mental toughness.

The passage describes a player named Wells, aged 23, who performed well in the T20 Blast last season, scoring 373 runs with an average of 28.69 and a strike rate of 138.66. Wells expresses enthusiasm about his team's progress and the positive coaching environment fostering a desire among teammates to be part of it.

The Reds won their second consecutive match against third-place Chinnor with a score of 29-12, securing fifth position in National Two South. Key players Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams were instrumental in leading the team. Coach Churcher attributes their success to strong tackling from the front row and front five. The Reds will face seven teams below them in their upcoming matches, including league leaders Old Elthamians. Churcher acknowledges room for improvement but emphasizes the need to maintain the spirited performance shown against Chinnor.

The passage describes a rape case involving a 74-year-old nun in Ranaghat, Kolkata. A 28-year-old man, identified as Nazrul or Nazu, is alleged to be the perpetrator. He was arrested at a railway station in Kolkata after fleeing to Bangladesh following identification from CCTV footage. The incident sparked public outrage and protests. Six arrests have been made in total, with eight suspects identified; two remain unlocated. Five of those arrested have implicated Nazrul as the rapist. The attack included theft from the convent school and damage to the building, culminating in the nun's rape within the premises.

The passage discusses how changes in technology, such as the domestic freezer and washing powder, along with cheaper imports, influenced what was available for purchase and popular among UK consumers. It mentions an interactive video featuring Robert Opie explaining these changes and their impact on brand rankings. The video also includes additional non-interactive content about ownership of brands in the UK and a survey ranking top consumer brands.

A 71-year-old woman from Sandyhills was scammed by someone posing as BT staff, gaining remote access to her computer and stealing money. A week later, another woman in Stranraer fell victim to a similar scam involving BT technical support. Both incidents highlight the ease with which scammers can gain access to computers, and emphasize the importance of not providing banking details or account numbers over the phone, as reputable businesses do not request such information.

Duffy, a 37-year-old Scotland assistant coach with experience at Leigh, Widnes, and Salford, has signed a one-year contract with third-place Championship team Featherstone. He will take charge of the team's final league match against Toulouse and prepare them for upcoming Super 8 Qualifiers. Chairman Mark Campbell expresses excitement about Duffy's potential impact, noting his commendable work at Swinton despite challenging conditions. Duffy replaces Stuart Littler at Swinton.

The Porthcawl RNLI crew, including a medic and a coastguard, responded to an emergency at Sker Beach, near Kenfig Nature Reserve, at 12:50 GMT on Sunday. A rider with head injuries and hypothermia was found unconscious on wet sand and was transported to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales after initial treatment.

The passage discusses the decision made at a UN conference in Geneva to allocate a radio frequency for a global satellite-based flight tracking system. This follows the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 in 2014, which highlighted gaps in the existing air navigation system. The new system, based on automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B) technology, aims to provide real-time tracking of all aircraft worldwide, addressing the 70% of airspace currently not covered by the current system. The initiative was spurred by the need for improved tracking capabilities, particularly following the loss of MH370, and is expected to be implemented by November 2016 with stricter guidelines for aircraft location reporting.

Julian Hernandez, a 18-year-old boy who disappeared at age 5, has been found and is now living with his father in Cleveland. Bobby Hernandez, 53, was arrested and is being held in Ohio for allegedly tampering with records to obtain a driver's license in 2012. The FBI confirmed the boy's identity through a tip about his college application issues and cooperation from Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children. Julian's mother has been informed of his recovery. Authorities have suspected Bobby Hernandez as the perpetrator since the boy's disappearance in 2002, when he reportedly fled after claiming he was taking Julian to pre-school.

The passage describes a fire at a waste management facility in Duncan Street on March 2nd, which disrupted train services and led to travel delays. Following the incident, the Environment Agency suspended the facility's ability to accept waste. Despite being broadly compliant with fire safety laws, the facility faced enforcement action due to concerns about potential impacts on nearby residents, transport, and the environment. Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service raised these concerns to the Environment Agency, resulting in joint inspections and eventual enforcement action. The facility has until August 7th to appeal the decision, during which time it must cease operations and remove all waste. The exact cause of the fire is unknown.

The passage discusses two bills proposed by Pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia. These bills aim to address separatist and pro-Russian sentiments in Ukraine's Crimea region, particularly focusing on Crimea's annexation and the issuance of Russian passports. The first bill suggests allowing a referendum or a request from a territory's leaders to trigger new provisions, while the second aims to expedite passport issuance procedures, emphasizing support for Russian-speaking Ukrainians. Both bills are seen as responses to the potential disintegration of Ukraine, with the intention of strengthening Russian influence in Crimea.

The passage discusses McLaren's tumultuous history in Formula One, highlighting their peak achievements under Honda engines in the late 1980s and early 1990s, including multiple championships and victories. However, the team has experienced significant downturns, particularly after 2013 when they struggled with chassis design and Honda power units. Despite these challenges, the team remains hopeful, believing that improvements in the car and Honda's engine could lead to future success, especially with the return of Fernando Alonso. The passage also touches on the leadership changes within the team, notably the return of Ron Dennis, and the expectations for McLaren to challenge Mercedes for the championship.

Thomas Baker, a 44-year-old from Everton, was fatally shot in the head and chest at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool's Old Swan area on 27 January. He died after being taken to the hospital. Three men, aged 29 and 32, were arrested and are currently in police custody for questioning. Baker had left Phoenix Gym at the market around the time of the shooting, which occurred while he was getting into his car. Detectives suspect the shooters had been waiting outside the gym for approximately an hour. A silver VW Polo is believed to have fled the scene at high speed, traveling along Balmoral Road, Molyneux Road, and Queens Road. Authorities are urging anyone with information or who has footage from the area to come forward.

This passage discusses various innovative ways to celebrate Christmas, including virtual church services, interactive games, and digital storytelling. It highlights how technology is being used to spread the message of Christmas, ranging from online sermons and virtual prayer requests to interactive games and digital adaptations of classic stories. The text also mentions efforts to reach diverse audiences, such as through Manga comics and social media platforms, emphasizing the adaptability of Christmas traditions in the digital age.

The eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is evaluating a request to take over 250 hectares of common land. Supporters, including Blaenau Gwent council, propose 320 hectares of replacement land. Experts have given differing opinions on the potential environmental impact of the proposed development, with Natural Resources Wales expressing doubt about the replacement's value but not opposing the project outright. An ecology report indicates a "net gain" in biodiversity due to enhancements elsewhere, while the Gwent Wildlife Trust disagrees. Ultimately, the Planning Inspectorate for Wales will provide a recommendation, followed by final approval by Welsh government ministers.

The passage discusses a meeting of Chechen Muslim clerics who condemned a report by Novaya Gazeta alleging that over 100 people, including influential Muslim clerics and Chechen TV presenters, were detained on suspicion of homosexuality in Chechnya. The clerics called for "retribution" against those responsible, potentially leading to violence against journalists. Novaya Gazeta, in response, urged authorities to protect journalists and investigate the allegations. The situation highlights homophobia and authoritarianism in Chechnya under Ramzan Kadyrov, with reports of torture and deaths among detainees. The incident also ties into broader patterns of human rights abuses and political repression in Chechnya, involving connections to other high-profile cases.

The passage discusses a controversial arrangement where a charity, Fresh Start Housing, refers homeless individuals to a letting agency, Investing Solutions, which then houses them in properties. Despite neither party acting illegally, there are concerns about the profitability and suitability of the housing provided. The arrangement is criticized as exploitative, with the bulk of housing benefit payments going to private landlords rather than the property owners. This leads to significant profits for Investing Solutions, which is one of the largest recipients of housing benefit in the UK. The practice is particularly criticized due to the high cost of housing for older homeless men, often exceeding the rent paid to the property owner. Critics argue that the system prioritizes profit over the welfare of the residents.

Andrew Lawrence and Ben Gordon scored 14 and 13 points respectively, helping their team lead for much of the game until the Dutch caught up late. The British team, coached by Joe Prunty, began their Eurobasket qualifying campaign against the Netherlands. Prunty emphasized the importance of intensity and teamwork in the upcoming qualifiers. Despite losing the game, Prunty praised Gordon's performance, noting it was his first points of the game and a positive sign for the team's development.

Conor McGregor submitted a waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission to fight Floyd Mayweather Jr., who uses 8oz gloves instead of the required 10oz gloves. The NAC will debate whether to allow the lighter gloves, citing health and safety concerns despite McGregor's experience with lighter gloves in his UFC career. The bout, expected to be the richest in history, is controversial among boxing personalities but approved by the NAC based on McGregor's performance against Nate Diaz and his overall boxing skills.

The passage discusses the decline and eventual closure of Fleet Street, a historic area in London renowned for its concentration of major newspapers. Former reporters Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith reflect on their careers in the area, noting significant changes over decades. They describe the vibrant, often chaotic environment of Fleet Street, including its role as a hub for journalism and its transition to a more casual, commercial setting. The passage also mentions the historical context, such as the founding of the Daily Courant and the importance of Fleet Street in disseminating information before the rise of television and social media. It highlights the impact of media mogul Rupert Murdoch's move of his publications to Wapping, leading to the decline of traditional Fleet Street operations. Finally, it concludes with personal reflections from current and former Fleet Street employees on the significance of the street's legacy and its place in journalistic history.

The passage discusses J.K. Rowling's response to abusive tweets and political donations, including her donation to the No campaign against Scottish independence and her stance on supporting the SNP despite receiving criticism. It also mentions her blocking of abusive Twitter users and her personal views on political parties.

The passage discusses how children from impoverished backgrounds are disproportionately affected by police interactions, violence, and involvement in the juvenile justice system. It highlights that living in poverty increases the likelihood of both boys and girls engaging in violent behavior, and that this effect is exacerbated by exposure to the criminal justice system. The study, conducted by the University of Edinburgh, underscores the interplay between poverty and criminal activity, suggesting that while efforts to reduce crime may be effective overall, they do not necessarily benefit the most disadvantaged communities.

A 25-year-old man named Mr. Haugh was stabbed in a laneway in the Marian estate in Kilkee. Robbie Walsh, from Island View, Kilrush, was charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr. Haugh. The incident occurred around 1 AM on Sunday when Walsh and two other men entered the Marian Estate looking for Mr. Haugh. During a fight involving weapons, Mr. Haugh received a stab wound to his back. He was taken to Limerick University Hospital where he died at 6 AM. Police found a knife handle and blade at the scene, both with blood. The case is ongoing, with Walsh remanded in custody pending further proceedings. There was mention of tensions in the area due to the killing.

Phil Flanagan, a Fermanagh MLA, tweeted a false accusation against Tom Elliott, who served in the UDR from 1982 to 1992. The tweet suggested Elliott had harassed and shot numerous individuals. This tweet was later deleted by Flanagan. Elliott's supporters, including Ann Travers and Arlene Foster, alerted the High Court to the tweet. Flanagan apologized and acknowledged the tweet was untrue. The case involves compensation and insurance coverage issues, with Flanagan challenging the insurer's refusal to cover him. Elliott expressed satisfaction with the resolution, noting it took longer than expected but was ultimately resolved.

Hawick Knitwear, established in 1874, has expanded its production to meet increased demand, particularly for its newly launched private label range that began selling in January. The company has seen growth in both its branded products and its service of supplying garments under private labels. It now produces approximately 9, 500 sweaters weekly, up from around 7, 500 last year. The firm operates in various European markets and has expanding international presence including the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan. The growth is attributed to strong orders from both domestic and foreign clients, and the company attributes its success to its dedicated workforce.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries when she was struck by Brian Wright, 55, while crossing Bedford Road in Kempston. Wright claims he was blinded by the setting sun and denies causing serious injury through dangerous driving. Despite this, the jury heard evidence that his vehicle failed to stop at a red light. Blackburn, who had been on duty for 20 years, is currently receiving treatment in residential care. Wright expressed deep remorse for his actions and their impact on Blackburn and her family. The case is ongoing.

The passage discusses a NATO exercise focusing on anti-submarine warfare against Russian submarines, highlighting concerns about Russia's growing naval capabilities and the UK's vulnerability due to a lack of maritime patrol aircraft. Key points include the increased patrols by Russian submarines, the challenges of detecting them, and the importance of training exercises for readiness. The exercise involves various types of vessels and technology, emphasizing the difficulty of tracking and engaging with stealthy submarines. It also underscores the need for coordinated efforts among NATO members and the necessity of addressing gaps in national defense capabilities.

The passage discusses the ongoing crisis in South Sudan, highlighting ethnic violence that has displaced over 340,000 people, primarily to neighboring Uganda. It describes the harrowing experiences of refugees fleeing violence, including killings, rapes, and forced displacement based on ethnicity. The conflict began between Dinka and Nuer groups, with Equatorians becoming targets in July. Uganda hosts the largest refugee settlement in the world, facing challenges such as providing adequate water and managing large numbers of children. The situation is described as a "massacre of civilians" requiring international intervention.

The passage describes McKenzie, aged 38, who will compete against Jahmaine Smyle at York Hall on 12 November for the English super-middleweight title. He transitioned from football to boxing in 2013, winning eight out of nine fights with one draw. McKenzie is the son of a former British and European champion and is trained by his uncle, a former world champion.

The passage discusses the planned construction of a new Bridgwater Community Hospital as part of a £330m investment by the coalition government for new NHS facilities in England. The new hospital will replace the existing 1813-built facility, which is described as cramped, outdated, and requiring frequent maintenance. It will include 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, and space for X-rays and mobile scanners. The total project cost is £33m, with the remainder funded by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. The new hospital aims to provide a more modern and comfortable environment for patients, enhancing their recovery process. This initiative follows recent renovations of other community hospitals in Somerset, and the construction is expected to be completed by autumn 2014, contingent upon obtaining planning permission.

A victim was fatally shot outside Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, near the city centre. He was found with a gunshot wound to his chest and was rushed to Northern General Hospital where he later died. The victim was reportedly a member of a family who were celebrating together when the shooting occurred. This incident is part of a series of recent shootings in Sheffield, though most have been in other areas of the city.

The passage describes various hacker groups involved in the conflict between Ukraine and separatist rebels in eastern Ukraine. Key points include:

- The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, conduct DDoS attacks and hack rebel websites.
- Cyber Berkut, an anti-Western group, targets Ukrainian government websites and leaks confidential documents.
- Anonymous International publishes leaked documents from the Kremlin and focuses on both Russia's and Ukraine's domestic affairs.
- These groups use a variety of tactics including DDoS attacks, hacking, and disrupting electronic systems to influence the conflict.

The passage discusses the farewell speeches of several departing members of the Scottish Parliament, including Alex Salmond, Duncan McNeil, and Annabel Goldie. It highlights Salmond's belief in Scotland's diversity and unity, his criticism of the Scotland Bill, and his humor. McNeil emphasized the importance of accountability and scrutiny in the Scottish Parliament, drawing parallels with Westminster. Goldie reflected on her interactions with the finance secretary. Overall, the speeches reflect the end of an era in Scottish politics as key figures step down ahead of the upcoming election.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, plans to gather firsthand accounts from pensioners and their supporters to assess the quality of life and care in residential facilities across Wales. This information will inform recommendations for both care providers and public bodies, stemming from her comprehensive review of older people's experiences in these settings. Her efforts aim to highlight both exemplary and problematic aspects of care, focusing on physical and psychological health, social interactions, and the living environment. By engaging directly with residents and stakeholders, Rochira seeks to foster understanding and drive improvements in service delivery.

Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, reported a pre-tax profit of £3. 5m in 2016, up from £2. 7m the previous year, despite a £1m drop in turnover to £100m. International sales increased, particularly in Europe and new markets. The company manufactures and supplies feeds for various livestock sectors and operates 19 shops under the Country Store brand, serving farming and rural communities. The outlook remains uncertain due to the difficulty in predicting the agricultural industry's future, though the board is confident in the group's ability to handle potential Brexit impacts.

A 70-year-old man was found dead at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted. An 80-year-old man was hospitalized. Police are seeking 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker, for questioning in connection with the murder. McLoughlin is described as white, about 6 feet tall, with straight, greying hair, and was last seen wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers, and a dark blue, light blue and white checked short-sleeved shirt with a button-down collar. The investigation is ongoing, and the public is advised to avoid approaching McLoughlin. Police are conducting patrols to reassure residents.

A summary of the passage is as follows: David Lipton, IMF's deputy managing director, discussed global economic risks in a speech to the National Association for Business Economics. He noted that the IMF's latest assessment of the global economy indicates a weakening trend, with the organization expecting to lower its global growth forecast to 3. 4% in April due to weak trade figures from China, which saw a significant drop in exports. This situation affects businesses and industries reliant on China's economic performance.

The council held a scrutiny meeting to address issues with a new ferry crossing at Cowes, initially free until July 7th to gather feedback. The council leader, Dave Stewart, announced a review by auditors after the ferry launched late on May 14th and faced breakdowns, grounding, and suspension. Businesses, particularly Angie Booth from Valu-4-U, expressed concerns about lost revenue due to the ferry's disruptions. Discussions included potential compensation for affected businesses and vehicles, with Ian Ward suggesting that while there were initial teething problems, the council authorized modifications to address vehicle scraping and grounded issues.

A fatal crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott around 07:30 GMT on Thursday. A 32-year-old man died at the scene. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested for causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road remained closed between Thursley and Liphook into the evening as police investigated.

The passage discusses allegations of discriminatory hiring practices by Matching Models, an international temp agency, which advertised for a personal assistant with specific physical attributes, including a "b-c cup" size, and a "sexy female driver" role. The Equality and Human Rights Commission and women's equality campaigners criticized these ads as offensive and potentially illegal under the 2010 Equality Act. The agency defended their practices, arguing that looks are important and citing examples of clients requiring specific physical characteristics for certain roles. However, legal experts and the commission contend that such advertisements violate anti-discrimination laws and could lead to legal action.

A shooting incident took place at a hostel connected to the Pragati Residential School in Bangalore, involving an alleged gunman named Mahesh, who was an office assistant there. The motive behind the shooting remains unclear. Mahesh allegedly killed 18-year-old Gautami and severely injured another student, Sirisha, before being apprehended. The shooter was held in remand until April 12th. This event is unusual given the rarity of gun crimes at educational institutions in India, where strict firearm regulations exist despite ongoing feuds.

The passage discusses an analysis by Glaad of LGBT representation in media from June 2016 to May 2017. It highlights an increase in transgender characters from seven to sixteen, but notes a concerning trend of over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters dying or being killed off. The report also points out a rise in black characters on broadcast television, particularly in shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. Despite these positive trends, Glaad's president Sarah Kate Ellis emphasizes that while progress is being made, it is only part of the story.

David Mackintosh, a Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced his resignation before a local party meeting where his candidacy faced opposition. He was criticized for a £10. 25 million loan to Northampton Town FC, which is now missing and under investigation for alleged financial irregularities. The loan was intended to rebuild Sixfields stadium and develop surrounding land, but the football stand remains unfinished. Mackintosh stated that he feels it is time for his constituents to elect a new representative.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old policeman, shot and killed Jordan Edwards, a 15-year-old teenager, after firing a rifle into a car driven by teens leaving a party in Balch Springs, Dallas. The incident occurred during an attempt to address underage drinking at the party. Police initially claimed the car reversed aggressively, but video evidence contradicted this. Oliver was subsequently dismissed for policy violations. He faces charges including murder and aggravated assault, with potential sentences up to 99 years in prison. The case marks the first conviction of a police officer for murder in Dallas County since 1973.

The passage discusses the potential relocation of the Trumps to the White House after Barron's completion of school. It highlights the unique situation of Melania Trump, the first First Lady not to reside in the White House during her husband's presidency, and explores historical precedents for such moves. The article also touches on the evolving role of First Ladies, noting that while the official role is primarily ceremonial, modern First Ladies often engage in public service and advocacy. The passage concludes by referencing previous instances of First Ladies taking on roles similar to Melania's, emphasizing the flexibility and adaptability of the position.

The passage describes the death of a 72-year-old man in Inverness on October 27th, leading to an investigation by the Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc) into the initial police response to his call. Police Scotland is cooperating with the investigation, and the findings will be reported to the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS).

The passage describes a yellow wind warning with gusts up to 75 mph, primarily affecting western areas near mountains. The unusual easterly wind direction is expected to intensify the effects. Travel disruptions are anticipated due to these conditions. Specific areas impacted include Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. A tree fell and closed a road in Anglesey, and cleanup efforts are ongoing.

A short-handed opening was played by Giants' coach Derrick Walser. Jeff Dimmen equalized for the Panthers. Mike Forney scored a powerplay goal, followed by Andy Bohmback's equalizer. Mike Radja and James Desmarais then scored, making the score 4-2. Nottingham's David Ling scored a comeback goal. The Giants and Panthers will play again on Saturday night as part of a double-header, with Nottingham leading the league standings.

The Chinese Grand Prix saw Lewis Hamilton start from the back due to a broken front wing and faced significant challenges including multiple pit stops. Despite these difficulties, Hamilton managed to overtake Sebastian Vettel and eventually finished third. However, he faces a substantial 36-point deficit in the championship standings. The race featured several incidents, including a collision between Vettel and Raikkonen on the first lap, which led to the safety car being deployed. Hamilton's poor luck in the early races is highlighted, as drivers who win the first three races rarely fail to secure the World Championship. Ferrari's strategy, choosing soft tires for their final stint, gave them an advantage over Mercedes. The race concluded with Mercedes' Nico Rosberg leading, while Hamilton struggled to close the gap to teammate and championship leader Nico Rosberg.

Thomas Hitzlsperger came out publicly to discuss the topic of homosexuality in German football, which was previously ignored. His announcement received widespread support from teammates, administrators, and figures in German football, including high-profile players and officials. This marks a significant step towards addressing homophobia in the sport, particularly in Germany, where it has been a challenging issue. The event is seen as a positive development that could encourage more athletes to openly share their sexual identities, potentially leading to a more inclusive environment within the sport.

Sidwell, 34, has contributed significantly to Brighton's promotion to the Premier League through 32 Championship appearances. His contract is set to expire, but he hopes to secure a new deal. The team clinched promotion after defeating Wigan and currently holds a four-point lead over Newcastle. Sidwell, who has played for various top-tier clubs including Reading, Chelsea, Aston Villa, Fulham, and Stoke, expresses ambition to return to the Premier League. He acknowledges that his performance exceeded expectations and is optimistic about negotiating a new contract.

The passage describes a football match between Blackpool and Colchester United that ended in a 1-1 draw. Blackpool scored first through Jamille Matt, but Colchester equalized via Kurtis Guthrie's header from a corner. The match saw several close calls and contentious moments, including a red card for Sean Murray of Colchester and a yellow card for Tom Eastman of Colchester. Both teams had chances to win the game late, but neither could secure the victory.

Colchester United's 29-year-old player, who has played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston, is set to make his debut for the club in an upcoming EFL Cup match against Aston Villa. Last season, he made 37 appearances for Sky Blues but they were relegated from League One. Colchester began their season with a loss to Accrington.

The murder of PC Keith Palmer outside the Houses of Parliament in March highlighted the need for a permanent memorial honoring police officers and staff. The UK Police Memorial Trust appealed for £1. 5 million to build the memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum, which will include the names of over 1, 400 officers and staff. The memorial aims to recognize the vital contributions of the police service and honor those who have sacrificed their lives. It is planned to be dedicated by 2019 and will feature a brass screen with leaf shapes cut out and given to families of fallen officers, along with the names of their loved ones. The government has committed £1 million towards the total cost of £4 million.

Manchester United maintained a 15-point lead at the top of the Premier League table after defeating Sunderland 1-0. Manager Sir Alex Ferguson emphasized focusing on upcoming matches, particularly the Manchester City derby, which they lead by 15 points. The team has an impressive recent record, winning 50 out of 54 points in their last 18 Premier League games. Ferguson plans to make changes for the FA Cup quarter-final replay against Chelsea due to injuries sustained during the Sunderland match. He anticipates that Wayne Rooney might need rest after his England international duties. The team showed resilience, especially in the second half, despite facing challenges from Sunderland.

The passage discusses Google's tax payments in the UK, stating they paid £10 million in corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011. Google asserts that they are complying with the legally required taxes and that the responsibility lies with the UK government to change its tax system if it wants companies to pay more. The company argues that taxes should be based on economic activity and risk-taking rather than consumption. Additionally, there is mention of a proposed committee to oversee major firm tax arrangements and a commitment to moving the tax debate forward with constructive engagement.

The passage discusses efforts by NHS Improvement to reduce the NHS's reliance on agency staff, which cost £3. 6bn last year. They aim to cut this by £1bn by the end of the current financial year. A cap on agency staff costs has been implemented, saving £600m so far, with only senior managers exempt. The goal is to reduce the overall cost and reliance on agency staff. However, despite progress, the NHS remains short of funds, with trusts 10% below target. The regulator plans to publish league tables and details on high earners to monitor performance and address discrepancies in agency rates.

The passage discusses the economic challenges faced by Longford Town Centre, particularly during the Republic of Ireland's economic crash. It highlights the decline in local businesses, such as Matt O'Brien's men's clothing shop, which saw a significant decrease in sales due to the economic downturn. Despite these difficulties, there are signs of improvement, with business increasing slightly and diversifying into childrenswear and dress-hire services. The passage also mentions criticism from the opposition party regarding the allocation of funds and the lack of foreign direct investment in the region. However, positive developments include the potential employment opportunities from the Center Parcs project and the local government's optimism about the area's natural attractions. Local traders express concerns about parking fees and suggest that further measures could aid economic recovery.

The passage describes a cricket tournament scheduled from April to May, featuring eight teams playing twice against each other. The top four teams qualify for play-offs. Notable statistics include leading run scorers and highest individual scores. The tournament fixtures and results are detailed, including specific match timings and venues. Additionally, it mentions that four current or former England players will participate. The final match takes place on 29 May in the same stadium where the competition concludes.

The passage discusses an increase in plastic carrier bag usage from 2013, highlighting environmental issues such as pollution in dumps and rivers. It mentions a 200 million rise in usage since then. A solution is proposed: a 5p fee on plastic bags in England starting from October, aimed at reducing bag waste and protecting the environment. In other regions like Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, where similar fees exist, there has been a reduction in bag usage.

The passage describes severe weather conditions affecting parts of Wales on Friday, including roof damage, power outages, train delays, and bridge restrictions. It mentions a yellow 'be aware' warning for wind across Wales, with the highest gusts recorded on Anglesey. Irish Ferries canceled some sailings due to adverse weather, and Arriva Trains Wales warned of potential delays. Several locations, including Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle, were closed by the National Trust due to high winds. The weather improved slightly by evening but remains forecasted for the Christmas weekend, leading to a postponement of the Rhyl Boxing Day Dip event.

The passage discusses an upcoming film where Jordan will reteam with director Ryan Coogler and actors Michael B. Jordan and Lupita Nyong'o. The film features Jordan reprising his role from the previous year's Fantastic Four, while Nyong'o returns from her role in Star Wars: The Force Awakens. The movie is set to release in February 2018. Jordan expresses excitement about the project and looks forward to working with Coogler and Nyong'o.

The passage describes plans to restore and refurbish Alexandra Palace, including a theatre, BBC studios, and the east wing. The theatre aims to host various performances like theatrical shows, cinema screenings, comedy, and live music. The BBC studios will also be repaired. If successful in fundraising, the theatre is expected to reopen in 2018. The project, supported by the Heritage Lottery Fund and Haringey Council, totals £26. 6 million. The restored area will include a glazed east court for public use and exhibitions. The theatre retains much of its original decor and stage machinery.

The passage discusses Jack Wilshere, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player who represented England in 61 senior matches from 2009. He participated in two World Cups and two European Championships but did not play in Euro 2016. The text also mentions that he holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 appearances since 2004, scoring his sole international goal in a 2014 World Cup qualifier against Moldova. Additionally, Wilshere expressed support for Sam Allardyce, the manager he worked under, wishing him and the team success in the future.

The passage describes a tragic house fire in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, where Marcy Smith's house was completely destroyed. Her family managed to escape, but their dog and cats perished. The fire was caused by burning rubbish in the wood stove, which did not trigger the fire alarm. Marcy Smith attributes her survival to her son David, who woke her up and helped them escape. Despite being dressed only in pajamas, the family received support from the community, including donations of clothing and a bike for David.

The energy drink company is reportedly considering a £200m bid for West Ham United Football Club. The club was previously purchased by Sullivan and Gold in 2010 for £105m, giving them a majority stake over 85%. Since moving to London Stadium in August, West Ham has been linked with potential takeovers from foreign investors like Qatar and China. Sullivan indicated last year that a minority share might be sold to settle debts, but the ownership would ultimately go to his children.

The passage describes an unconventional awards ceremony that included fan-voted categories such as best kiss and best shirtless performance. It highlights the official winners including The Fault in Our Stars for best movie, Shailene Woodley for best female performance, and Bradley Cooper for best male performance. The event also featured special awards and tributes, such as the Trailblazer Award for Woodley, and a Generation Award presented to Robert Downey Jr., honoring the Avengers team. Additionally, the ceremony showcased clips from upcoming films and celebrated the promotion of summer blockbusters through entertainment and humor.

The passage discusses a loan move where Smith, a 21-year-old player from Aberdeen, joined Dundee United in July and has scored five goals this season. Smith previously played for Aberdeen, making his debut in 2012 and scoring four times in 89 appearances. Aberdeen manager Jack Ross praised Smith, calling him a "brilliant acquisition" who fits well with the team's attacking strategy. The passage also mentions that St Mirren, hosting Falkirk in the Championship, is benefiting from Smith's presence.

The Northumberland County Council plans to use Jetpatcher machines to fill 145 potholes daily over the next four months, addressing both existing holes and damage caused by recent weather conditions such as heavy rain and debris in gutters. Additional staff will be deployed to repair drainage systems.

A rigging supervisor and his colleagues at EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while working on a shutdown project. They were unaware of the potential radiation risk until after the work began. Despite being exposed for several hours, the levels were below the threshold for reporting to the Health and Safety Executive. The incident led to concerns about long-term health effects and calls for improved safety protocols. EnQuest and Wood Group both emphasized their commitment to employee safety, though the rigging supervisor expressed dissatisfaction with the handling of the situation and called for legal action.

The Asian Civilisation Museum purchased a bronze sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 in 2007 from a New York dealer accused of trafficking stolen Indian antiquities. The sculpture was allegedly stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, India. After the dealer's admission of dealing in looted artifacts, the sculpture was returned upon request from the Indian Archaeological Survey of India. The museum intends to pursue legal action for potential fraud involving other items purchased from the same dealer.

The passage describes a magnitude-4. 8 earthquake occurring at a depth of 15. 5 km, 35 km north of Lucca, Italy. It affected areas including Milan, Florence, and nearby cities, though there were no immediate reports of injuries or damage. The earthquake was part of Italy's history of seismic activity, with a notable example being a 2009 quake in L'Aquila that killed nearly 300 people. The current event was described as a medium-strong and fairly shallow earthquake by experts. It caused some disruption, including power cuts and school evacuations, but no significant damage was reported. The passage also mentions previous legal proceedings related to earthquake predictions in L'Aquila.

The passage describes Austin Grant, a 62-year-old grandfather from Sheffield, who initially doubted the climate's suitability for growing fruit. Despite this skepticism, he has observed results and expressed great joy upon seeing the fruit still attached to the plant and not yet ripe for consumption.

The passage discusses the delay of Grand Theft Auto V's release from January 27th to March 24th due to additional testing and polishing. Rockstar assures fans this delay is for their benefit. Additionally, it mentions the inclusion of online heists on consoles before the PC release. The passage also highlights the improved visuals and resolutions available in the PC version, and provides details about the minimum system requirements needed to play the game. Lastly, it notes that the game sold over one billion dollars worth of revenue in its first three days upon release.

The passage discusses an artist named Simpson who won £25, 000 for their artwork "Squint (19)" at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery. This piece was one of several shortlisted in 1991 and was chosen by judge Ansel Krut as "quite extraordinary," despite being difficult to look at. Simpson, who has been shortlisted three times before, expressed joy at finally winning. The artwork depicts medieval leper squints and is part of a series of paintings. Simpson chose the small size of "Squint (19)" for the competition and plans to use the prize money for materials. Krut praised the painting, describing it as a "tone poem" that builds a picture over time and having sympathetic subject matter. The John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain's oldest art awards, with notable past winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig.

A pair of pro-government Turkish newspapers, Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, were attacked by masked assailants who fired guns through their windows, shattering them. Both papers supported the ruling AK Party of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan. The attacks occurred simultaneously near each other's locations, with no casualties reported. The assailants were identified as four masked individuals, and firefighters quickly contained the fire. Police have secured the area and are searching for the attackers. No group has yet claimed responsibility for the attacks. This incident follows previous violence against pro-government media outlets, such as the attack on Hurriyet's offices last September.

A 24-year-old player, who previously played for Buriton and scored three goals in 23 games on loan at Crawley, is joining the Mariners on a free transfer effective from January 1st, becoming the team's first signing under manager Marcus Bignot.

The passage discusses Arsene Wenger's potential departure from Arsenal and his link to the England national team manager position. It mentions Eddie Southgate's recent appointment as England manager, his performance, and his upcoming matches. The text also includes information about Wenger's stance on the role and his comments on extending Hector Bellerin's contract and Aaron Ramsey's injury status.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road is believed to have fallen from a cherry picker around 13:45 GMT on Thursday. This incident is being investigated jointly by Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive, with the company's cooperation.

A new charter arrangement between Serco Northlink and Seatruck has ended a dispute over seafarers' pay on two freight boats serving the Northern Isles. Initially, the RMT union alleged that some crew members were paid less than £4 per hour. Under the new terms, contracted out services for these vessels will revert to Serco Northlink from next month. Despite repeated offers to bridge the pay gap and backdate it, Seatruck refused to accept them. Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced that the new arrangements will ensure all crew members are paid at least the national minimum wage, effective early next month.

The passage describes the death of Ken Dickie, 64, who passed away in hospital six days after an incident involving his son Jamie Mitchell, 35, and his mother Samantha Mitchell, 57, at Rockley Park in Poole. Jamie Mitchell admitted intervening in an argument between his mother and his father, leading to a fight. He was convicted of common assault and lied to the police about the circumstances of the incident, which involved both Mitchell and Dickie pushing each other during a confrontation. The case is set to be sentenced on February 6th.

Rod Temperton, a prolific British songwriter known for his contributions to Michael Jackson's "Off The Wall" and "Thriller," passed away at the age of 66 after a brief battle with cancer. His hits include "Boogie Nights," "Rock With You," and "Baby Be Mine." Temperton's songwriting career began in the 1970s when he joined Heatwave and later worked with Quincy Jones on Michael Jackson's albums. He received critical acclaim and accolades, including a Grammy Award and Oscar nominations. Temperton's influence extended beyond his collaborations with Jackson, as his songs were also recorded by artists such as Anita Baker and Aretha Franklin. Temperton was known for his low-profile persona and credited his father's influence for his musical talent.

The passage describes the discovery of ancient earthworks, known as geoglyphs, in the western Brazilian Amazon. These structures, possibly dating back 2,000 years, were hidden under dense bamboo-dominated rainforest until recent deforestation revealed over 450 large geometric formations. The researchers, including Dr. Neil Loader from Swansea University, suggest these sites were not used for defensive purposes but rather as ritual gathering places, possibly akin to Maya pyramids or Stonehenge. The study reveals that the surrounding vegetation was taller than previously thought, indicating that the geoglyphs were not visible above the canopy. This finding challenges the notion of pristine Amazonian forests and suggests that ancient inhabitants managed the landscape through selective tree planting, creating an artificial ecosystem rich in economically valuable plants.

The passage describes 21-year-old Kyrgios defeating world number 29 Querrey in a 6-4, 6-4 match in 53 minutes, advancing to the second round. Kyrgios, who has reached a career-high world ranking of 12th, won the Japan Open and is nearing the top 10. He attributed his subdued performance to fatigue and lack of sleep due to travel and competition in Japan.

The passage discusses the potential benefits of the HPV vaccine in preventing head and neck cancers, particularly among younger individuals, including both males and females. It highlights an increase in head and neck cancer cases, especially among non-smoking men. The Welsh government is considering implementing a vaccination program for boys, based on advice from experts like Dr. Mererid Evans and organizations such as Tenovus Cancer Care and Cardiff University's HPV research team. However, the government has yet to make a final decision, awaiting guidance from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old student diagnosed with gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, attended a school prom in his honor before passing away. His mother shared his Facebook page where he documented his journey, showing his love for Rangers FC and meeting former and current footballers. Despite feeling unwell, Jak managed to attend the prom for 10 minutes. His story and positive attitude inspired many, leading to a fundraising campaign for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research. Jak's illness progressed rapidly, and he passed away shortly after learning his cancer had spread.

Egypt defeated Uganda 1-0 in a tightly contested match where Mohamed Salah assisted Abdallah El Said to score the winning goal in the 89th minute. Despite Uganda's efforts, including a disallowed goal due to offside, they were unable to find an equalizer. This result leaves Egypt advancing to play Ghana in the next round, while Uganda faces Mali in their final group match.

The passage discusses the potential repurposing of land from two closed educational institutions, Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College, for rail infrastructure. Network Rail conducted a study comparing these sites and another nearby option. Skelmersdale, designated as a new town in 1961 but lacking a railway station, could benefit from two direct hourly trains to Liverpool if the chosen site is acquired. The preferred location offers ample space for future expansion and convenient transportation links. Lancashire County Council is moving forward with the acquisition process.
A man was arrested and plants suspected to be from an elaborate grow house were found during a search of a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning.

A 28-year-old Kurdish German woman from Hamelin was seriously injured and dragged through several streets by her ex-partner, who later turned himself in to the authorities. The attacker, a 38-year-old man from Bad Muender, is also of Kurdish descent. The motive for the attack remains unclear, and police are seeking witnesses and securing the scene.

The passage discusses a study conducted by Cass Business School and other institutions examining pay rise requests among full-time male and female workers in Australia. Contrary to the "reticent female" theory suggesting women avoid asking for pay increases, the study found that women and men were equally likely to request raises. However, men were 25% more likely to receive pay increases after requesting them. The research excluded part-time workers to ensure comparability and considered factors such as employer size, industry, parenthood status, and qualifications. The study challenges the notion that women are reluctant to ask due to fear of upsetting their bosses or deviating from gender stereotypes. The findings suggest that women may be more open about their experiences, leading to higher rates of reported rejections. The study also noted that younger workers (under 40) showed similar rates of asking and receiving pay increases, indicating potential changes in negotiation behavior over time.

The Oxford City Council has been searching for a new burial site due to lack of suitable land within the city. Ground investigations of potential sites have revealed unsuitable conditions such as size, ground conditions, and restrictions. Two cemeteries, Wolvercote and Botley, are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021 respectively, necessitating alternative burial methods like reopening family plots and interment of ashes. The council has not found a suitable new burial site despite ongoing exploration.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, held in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, offers visitors an augmented reality app that allows them to access online information and videos from festival signs and posters. Featured artists include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. Director Caroline Maclennan highlights the app as enhancing the festival experience for both attendees and those unable to attend, providing real-time updates on festival activities, ticket purchasing, and a virtual tour of the event.

A ten-year-old Irish-bred horse collapsed during the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day, suffering from severe pulmonary haemorrhage despite having no significant underlying health issues. The horse, King George winner Thistlecrack's rival Many Clouds, had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia but had never collapsed before. Despite previous overheating episodes, trainer Oliver Sherwood described Many Clouds as the "horse of a lifetime." Veterinary staff treated the horse before its death, and the British Horseracing Authority noted that such episodes are rare, occurring even in healthy horses without apparent pre-existing conditions.

A 15-year-old girl, now 34 and identified as Davina, is facing charges of raping a 15-year-old boy in a Portsmouth garage in 2004. The defendant, who has learning difficulties, denies the charges. She was remanded into custody after a trial, likely to be held in a male prison due to concerns about her potential risk to herself and non-attendance. The incident occurred when Davina was alone with the victim, who managed to shout and swear at her attacker. This case was unusual and difficult for the court, which took note of Davina's suicide attempt in the previous year and her disclosure about the assault to a care home worker in 2014.

The passage describes a tennis match where Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares defeated the Serbs 6-4, 6-4 in Rio. It also mentions that Novak Djokovic, who had previously been eliminated from the singles at Wimbledon by Juan Martin del Potro, won his 30th Masters title in Toronto prior to the Olympics. The text indicates that Djokovic is the world number one but was unexpectedly defeated in the third round of Wimbledon.

The passage describes an annual carving competition scheduled for Saturday in Carrbridge within the Cairngorms region. Competitors include carvers from various countries such as Scotland, England, Ireland, and Europe, as well as North America. Participants are restricted to using chainsaws to transform logs into animal and human figures. Pete Bowsher, who won last year, will defend his title and keep the Claymore Trophy.

Webb, who has not played since a World Cup warm-up injury, is nearing a return to action. He expects to be fit for the Six Nations in February after taking time to recover. His return date was initially planned for early February, but he secured additional weeks to prepare. Webb will begin his season with Wales against Ireland on 7 February. He has renewed his contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, choosing to remain with the region despite interest from other clubs.

A group of individuals attempting to smuggle MDMA across the US-Canada border near Sumas, Washington, was intercepted by border agents on Tuesday. One of the suspects, Jeffrey Laviolette, resisted arrest by firing a weapon and fleeing, while Nathan Hall was apprehended shortly after. Additional suspects, including Kali Henifin and Ryan Lambert, were also arrested. The confiscated backpacks contained 58lb (26kg) of ecstasy, and false identification was found. All four individuals face charges related to drug trafficking and conspiracy. This area is known for its use in drug smuggling activities.

The passage discusses an increase in the number of children seeking counseling through the NSPCC's Childline service, rising from approximately 2, 400 in 2011-12 to over 4, 500 in the previous year. It highlights that many children, including some as young as seven, experience online abuse and bullying, which can lead to severe emotional distress and even suicidal thoughts. The article emphasizes the impact of cyberbullying, stating that it can continue beyond school hours and worsen if left unchecked. It also mentions that Childline's president, Dame Esther Rantzen, believes intervention by adults, parents, and teachers is crucial to prevent bullying from escalating. Additionally, the passage notes that Anti-Bullying Week is underway, with support from various organizations aiming to address bullying issues among children.

The passage discusses the US decision not to veto a UN Security Council resolution condemning Israeli settlement construction, leading to tensions between the US and Israel. This decision was seen as influenced by the US, angering Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. The Israeli settlements, totaling over 500, 000 residents, are considered illegal under international law but are disputed by Israel. Following this, Israel's Jerusalem Planning and Housing Committee initially planned to authorize new homes in settlements, but postponed the vote after being requested by the prime minister's office to avoid exacerbating relations with the US, ahead of US Secretary of State John Kerry's speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

The passage discusses various events surrounding Queen Elizabeth II's 90th birthday celebration, including a BBC interview where she is praised as a "guiding example" of a good monarch. It mentions the release of stamps honoring the Queen and her family, and details of her official birthday celebrations, which include a walk around Windsor, unveiling a plaque, lighting a beacon, and a state dinner with US President Obama. The article also touches on Prince William's views on royal duty and his father's role as monarch.

West Ham United scored two early goals against League Two side Cheltenham Town, taking control of the match before halftime. Despite efforts from both teams, particularly from Cheltenham Town, West Ham United maintained their lead. The game concluded with a score of 2-0 in favor of West Ham United. Cheltenham Town had several close moments but failed to capitalize on their opportunities, leading to their elimination from the EFL Cup.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, died in a motorcycle accident caused by Andreas Werner, a 46-year-old man from Leipzig, when Werner failed to see the motorcyclist turning right. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving and was fined £1, 000 with a two-year ban from driving in the UK. His family accepted his guilt but did not seek imprisonment, citing it as a momentary lapse.

Imran Khawaja, a British jihadist, returned from fighting in Syria where he posted videos and pictures of his activities. He was part of the group Rayat al Tawheed, known for producing slick, well-produced propaganda appealing to young British Muslims. After returning to the UK, he attempted to evade authorities by faking his death and concealing his entry. Despite facing potential life imprisonment, his motivations remain unclear.

Kayden Jackson, aged 22, scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season, helping them finish eighth in the league table. He has been signed by Barnsley for the upcoming season, ahead of their League One play-off final. The club's caretaker manager, Paul Heckingbottom, praised Jackson's pace and attacking style, stating he will integrate well with Barnsley's playing philosophy. Jackson declined a new contract with Wrexham.

The passage describes bottles found washed ashore at various Cornish coastal locations, primarily Poldhu Cove, after being reported to pose a risk to wildlife. Initially, National Trust volunteers were clearing these bottles, which were sealed but reportedly leaking. The National Trust believes the bottles came from a container that went overboard from a ship during a storm near Land's End in May. However, the Maritime and Coastguard Agency disputes this, stating that there is no conclusive evidence linking the washed-up bottles to the specific container. The bottles are believed to contain 'Vanish' detergent, raising concerns among conservationists about their potential negative impact on marine life. Other nearby coves have also been affected. Authorities are monitoring the situation and advising caution around the bottles.

A crash happened on the A9 near Berriedale in Caithness around 14:00, resulting in several minor injuries. The road was closed and traffic rerouted via the A897. Police are investigating the incident further.

Dervite, 28, played 14 games for Wanderers in League One, helping them finish second and securing promotion to the Championship. He joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has made 83 appearances in total. Manager Phil Parkinson praised his performance towards the end of the season. Bolton also signed new contracts for Dervite and other defenders, as they prepare for their move to the Championship.

The passage discusses tensions between the Liberal Democrats (Lib Dems) and Labour over Brexit, specifically regarding amendments related to EU citizens' rights and parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal. Initially, both parties cooperated to defeat government measures, but this unity broke down after MPs rejected the amendments. Lib Dems insisted on the amendments while Labour deferred to the Commons. Labour criticized the Lib Dems for misleading voters and building false hope, while the Lib Dems accused Labour of aligning with the Conservatives on a hard Brexit. Historically, these parties have formed alliances to oppose government legislation, but recent disagreements suggest potential strain in their cooperation.

The passage discusses the declining importance of defense spending in UK politics, influenced by economic priorities and public sentiment. It highlights the reduction in military personnel and capabilities, including the shrinking size of the regular army, navy, and air force. The UK's defense spending has decreased significantly, falling from the fourth-largest spender to sixth, and is projected to fall below NATO's 2% GDP target. Despite this, various political parties have pledged to maintain or increase defense budgets, leading to uncertainty about future defense spending cuts. The debate centers on renewing the Trident nuclear deterrent, maintaining continuous at-sea deterrence, and the potential for further reductions in conventional forces. The passage also mentions the challenges posed by the construction of new aircraft carriers, which may strain manpower resources. Overall, the article underscores the complex and contentious nature of UK defense policy amidst broader economic and strategic considerations.

Barcelona insists they did not commit an offense regarding the Neymar transfer. They claim the initial £48. 6 million fee plus various additional costs totals £106. 8 million. The club has paid a tax declaration of 13, 550, 830. 56 euros to clarify their fiscal obligations. Despite these actions, a judge in Spain continues to investigate potential tax-related crimes related to the transfer.

A 27-year-old man named Michael Luciw, who was a delivery driver, died in a motorway collision caused by an older driver, Albert Kenneth Newman, who was also killed. His family advocates for regular driving tests for older individuals and suggests that retired drivers should undergo medical examinations. Michael was a loving father-to-be, and his death has left his family devastated. The incident occurred on October 12th, 2022, near Kegworth, Leicestershire, where Newman was driving the wrong way on the motorway. The family believes that if Newman had undergone a medical examination, such accidents could be prevented.

The passage discusses concerns over transvaginal mesh implants used to treat urinary incontinence. Women have reported severe side effects leading to questioning the safety of these implants. An independent review was conducted, but two members quit in protest. Professor Alison Britton, a healthcare and medical law expert, will now examine the final report. The review concluded that the procedures should not be offered routinely to women with pelvic organ prolapse and recommended alternative treatments and informed patient choices. However, despite the findings, the government maintains that the procedures cannot be banned due to regulatory authority. The review faced challenges in achieving consensus among its members, and some experts resigned due to dissatisfaction with the report. Over 20,000 women in Scotland have received these implants, with many experiencing complications, leading to ongoing legal actions.

Laura Muir broke the 25-year-old record held by McColgan by 14 seconds at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow, running a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds. This record-breaking performance led to discussions about the validity of the race due to its format, including the absence of a 3K race and potential doping controls. Despite these concerns, British Athletics confirmed that Muir's time would be considered official. McColgan, Muir's coach, expressed confidence in Muir's abilities, noting her potential to improve further and compete with the best in the world.

The passage discusses the results of an equestrian competition where Jung won aboard Sam, a late replacement due to illness. France's Astier Nicolas secured silver, and Phillip Dutton took bronze for the United States. William Fox-Pitt from Great Britain finished 12th, having previously dropped to 21st after time penalties in the cross-country phase. Fox-Pitt, a three-time Olympic medalist, was competing just 10 months after recovering from a coma. His performance improved in the show-jumping phase, but his medal hopes were hampered by poor show-jumping results. Ireland's Jonty Evans came in ninth place.

Andy Murray, aged 30, defeated Fognini, the 29th seed, in a grueling match lasting two hours and 39 minutes. The match was particularly intense as it ended late into the evening, with Murray securing a crucial point at 20:57 BST. Despite facing multiple set points from Fognini, Murray managed to win five games in a row to advance to the next round. Murray will face Benoit Paire in the fourth round on Monday. The match showcased moments of tension and drama, including a potential fifth-set scenario due to the fading light, and a controversial exchange where Fognini received a penalty point for an obscene gesture. Murray expressed satisfaction with his performance, noting that while he did not feel his best, he managed to secure the victory.
